job.title: Machine Learning Engineer
job.description:
As part of a high performing global team, the right candidate will play a hands-on role in the design and development for implementing Machine learning best practices in network traffic data collection, processing, analysis, and monitoring.

 

Responsibilities :-

  • Design, develop and maintain key frameworks, services and applications for network traffic data collection, processing, analysis, correlation, and monitoring in Cloud Products. 
  • Experience with applying statistical distribution analysis to data.
  • Hands on experience in designing batch-based, real-time streaming and event-based data solutions (Spark, Storm, Flink etc. Kafka expertise highly desired)
  • Proficient with microservices-based, API/Endpoint architectures
  • Experience in network traffic data collection, processing, analysis, and monitoring, and solid understanding of protocols TCP/IP, IPv4/IPv6, NetFlow, sFlow, IPFix. Netconf/Yang
  • Understanding of concepts of Radius, PPPoE IP, DHCP IP, SNMP.
  • Highly proficient in Java, Go, Nodejs, Scala, or similar programming languages.
  • Experience in building and productizing cloud-based/scale data ingestion (preferably in AWS)
  • Experience in cloud data solutions like Elastic, Greenplum, Redshift or like technologies a plus. 
  • 5 -10 years of highly technical, hands-on software engineering experience. Independent and Self driven and works in a Team.
  • Customer facing engineering role in debugging and resolving field issues.
  • Participate and drive technical discussions within engineering group in all phases of the SDLC: review requirements, produce design documents, participate in Peer reviews, produce test plans, support QA team, provide internal training and support TAC team. 
  • Organized and goal-focused, ability to deliver in a fast-paced environment.
  • Strong, creative problem-solving skills and ability to abstract and share details to create meaningful articulation.
  • Implementation background in various data processing, consumption patterns, and pipelines.
